title: Understanding Lactate Levels and Fat Oxidation
content: Lactate levels, fat oxidation, and the relationship between watts and lactate are discussed. It is noted that carbohydrates in food can affect lactate levels. Equal lactate outputs in an athlete and a metabolically unhealthy individual can mean different things and interpreting this is important. The specifics around Zone 2 exercise are discussed, including what metrics to use to know if you’re in Zone 2, how to structure an ideal Zone 2 training program without a lactate meter with regards to duration, timing, frequency, and the importance of compounding the rate of improvement that can happen with Zone 2 training.

title: VO2 Max and High Intensity Training
content: VO2 max and high intensity training are discussed, including where they fit in with overall Zone 2 training and how exercise can have a large impact on longevity.

title: Metformin and Mitochondrial Health
content: The potential impact of Metformin on the mitochondria is discussed, as well as claims that NAD can boost mitochondrial health. The difference between healthy and unhealthy mitochondria is also discussed.

title: Long COVID and Mitochondrial Effects
content: A study on long COVID patients revealed effects on the mitochondria that were reminiscent of type 2 diabetes.

title: Assessing Athletic Performance in Cyclists
content: The use of physiological testing to reveal a cyclist's capabilities is discussed, including the ability to clear lactate and sustain a high amount of power for long periods of time. The use of software to track a cyclist's ability to sustain a given power output for the whole day or a specific glycolytic effort is also mentioned.

title: The Impact of Performance-Enhancing Drugs
content: The impact of performance-enhancing drugs on cycling is discussed, including the difference in power output when using EPO and blood transfusions. The potential for transparency into athletes’ data during competition is also discussed.

title: Defining Zone 2 and Fat Oxidation
content: Zone 2 training is characterized by a high level of fat oxidation. As exercise intensity increases, the fatmax starts to go down sharply. Fat oxidation can be measured using an indirect calorimeter and an ergometer. The ratio of VO2 and VCO2 will tell how much energy is made from fat oxidation and how much of it is glycolytic.

title: Oxidation of Fats and Carbohydrates
content: As exercise intensity increases, one needs more oxygen. In a lipolytic state, a more fatty oxygenation state, you still consume oxygen, but you do not produce as much CO2. In a more glycolytic state, which occurs at higher exercise intensity, you’re using more glucose for energy purposes, consuming more oxygen and producing more CO2.

title: Metabolism of Elite Athletes
content: Elite athletes have an amazing fat oxidation capacity compared to other competitive athletes. This reflects what’s happening in the mitochondria and how the mitochondria oxidizes those fuels at different exercise intensities. For example, at an intensity of 200 watts (W), an elite athlete does not use their glycolytic capacity as much a someone who is not well trained. The elite athlete can still recruit slow twitch muscle fibers and rely on fat to produce ATP because they have amazing mitochondrial function and are very efficient, metabolically speaking.

title: Lactate Levels and Fat Oxidation in Relation to Zone 2 Exercise
content: The change in blood lactate levels as workload increases can be used to define Zone 2 training. Resting blood lactate levels are going to be used more and more as a biomarker, like resting blood glucose levels. In patients with type 2 diabetes or profound metabolic syndrome their resting blood lactate levels are 1.5-3 mmol. Increasing lactate beyond 2 mmol indicates movement from Zone 2 to Zone 3.

title: Analysis of Fat Oxidation Changes as Workload Increases
content: The fitter the individual, the higher their absolute capacity for fat oxidation. A fit individual will actually increase fat oxidation to a local maxima before that oxidation begins to decline whereas most mortals begin at a maximum and decline from there. Fat oxidation is easy to calculate via indirect calorimetry.

title: Relating Maximum Fat Oxidation to Zone 2 Exercise
content: Zone 2 should be redefined as the place where maximum fat oxidation occurs. Using a blood lactate level of 2 mmol might be too much. Everything is related to the lactate kinetics and lactate oxidation in the mitochondria.

title: Relating Lactate Levels to Metabolic Stress in Individuals at Different Fitness Levels
content: The same blood lactate concentration in an elite athlete does not correspond to the same metabolic stress in a recreational athlete. A patient with metabolic syndrome can exercise for a couple hours with a blood lactate level of 2.5 mmol. A professional athlete is going to be hurting at that lactate level.

title: Metabolism of Lactate
content: When someone has high power output, they need a lot of glycolysis to provide that energy; this will produce lactate. Lactate is the mandatory obligatory byproduct, not waste product, but byproduct of glycolysis. So the higher the glycolysis, the higher the lactate. Lactate has 2 routes it can take: 1) Lactate can go from the fast twitch muscle fibers to the slow twitch muscle fibers. 2) Lactate can be exported to the blood.

title: Training to Improve Metabolic Function and Maximize Mitochondrial Performance
content: The moderately active individual hits 2 mmol lactate at 175 watts but max fat oxidation at 125 watts. To improve metabolic function, mitochondrial performance, fuel flexibility, Zone 2 should be defined somewhere in the middle of these two values.

title: Bioenergetics of the Cell and Differences in Elite Athletes
content: The cell uses 2 main substrates for fuel: fatty acids and pyruvate, but also lactate. Lactate acts as an extra fuel, but to utilize it, these transporters must be expressed. These transporters are downregulated in people who are sedentary. This is what is different in professional athletes. Fast twitch muscle fibers use glucose. During high intensity exercise requires glucose. Using glucose as a fuel always results in the production of pyruvate. Higher intensity exercise results in the production of more pyruvate and then more lactate.

title: Muscle Fibers and Glucose Oxidation
content: The mitochondria in slow twitch muscle fibers don’t use fat; they rely on glucose. The moment they start using glucose, they produce lactate. However, they cannot oxidize the lactate; this is why it is exported to the blood. Well-trained athletes use more glucose. Indirect calorimetry of recreational athletes or people with metabolic syndrome shows a maximum of 4 g/min carbohydrate oxidation. Elite athletes can get to 6.5 gram/ min; this is a massive amount of glucose oxidation. And elite athletes will produce more lactate. But the key is, it doesn’t show up in the blood because it’s oxidized in the muscle. This correlates a lot with fat oxidation as well.

title: Ketogenic Diets and Exercise
content: How the level of carbohydrate in the diet and ketogenic diets affects fuel utilization and power output during exercise. Metrics of cellular metabolism when on a ketogenic diet. Ketosis is an extreme example, but given how much the respiratory quotient (RQ; the ratio of VCO2 to VO2) depends on baseline carbohydrate intake— how do you adjust the definition of Zone 2.

title: Glutamine and ICU Patients
content: Glutamine can be used as a fuel and to generate glucose. There is a 3rd element that is key in bioenergetics— glutamine. Glutaminase it’s highly expressed and utilized; it converts the amino acid glutamine to glutamate (which can enter the Krebs cycle). ICU patients express tremendous levels of glutamine because they need it to either enter the Krebs cycle for energy or for gluconeogenesis. ICU patients also have hyperglycemia. In the acute ICU phase, they also have insulin resistance. Their hyperglycemia is off the charts. They are not going to get IVs of glucose. These patients benefit from receiving protein.

title: Exercise and Glucose Transporters
content: Once you exercise, you have insulin resistance and difficulty translocating GLUT4 transporters to the surface of the muscle. These move glucose into the cell. Skeletal muscle is probably the first tissue where diabetes starts because around 80% of the carbohydrates we have are oxidized in skeletal muscle. But with insulin resistance, GLUT4 transporters cannot be translocated. But there is a second way to move those transporters that not many people know about— that’s muscle contraction. Muscle contraction is insulin-independent mechanism of translocating GLUT4 transporters to the cell surface.

title: Zone 2 Training
content: Metrics for characterizing Zone 2 training. In a patient or a world class athlete you have the ability to do indirect calorimetry and lactate testing to determine Zone 2 training. But training normal people is different. The lactate measured in the blood is heavily influenced by production and clearance. The gold standard would be to measure fat oxidation. But even this can be confounded in people on a ketogenic diet.

title: Heart Rate and Exercise
content: For people who have not done a metabolic test, heart rate is a good guide. First you need to determine your maximum heart rate (not the predicted maximum). For less trained people, this % is lower. He tells patients to start at a broad range of 70-80% of their realized maximum heart rate. Then make adjustments based on their rating of perceived exertion.

title: Fatigue and Glycogen Stores
content: When you don’t have enough glycogen storages, it’s very possible that adrenal activity is decreased. You need to break down glycogen; this requires glycogen phosphorylase in the muscle and that’s directly regulated by catecholamines. Iñigo’s hypothesis is that when there is decreased glycogen stores, the brain says, “I don’t care about your legs, don’t use up all the glycogen because you have to give it to me”. The brain doesn’t shut down glycogen degradation, but it slows it down by releasing less catecholamines. The collateral effect of that is a lower heart rate; catecholamines also regulate heart contractility (they increase heart rate). So a lower level of catecholamines results in a lower heart rate.

title: Optimal Zone 2 Training
content: Advice for the person new to Zone 2 training. High intensity training is not enough.

title: Exercise Duration and Frequency
content: You can accomplish very important mitochondrial adaptations and very important metabolic adaptations by exercising one hour. Aim for 1 – 1.5 hour. If you only train once a week, chances are your mitochondrial function will deteriorate over time, especially as you age. 2 days a week might maintain what you have. 3 days a week will start to show results. 4 days a week is ideal for sure. 5-6 days a week are ideal; but not everybody has 6 days a week to train. 4-5 days a week of training is achievable for most people. Put aside 1-1.5 hours. For a mere mortal, somebody just starting out who may not be fit, you can’t start off with 1 hour. Start with 20, 30, or 40 minutes. Gradually build up to a 1 hour walk or run. If you bike, 1 hour 20 minutes or an hour and a half, 4 days a week is good.

title: High Intensity Training
content: There is a need for some high intensity too. From a lens of health, the data are unambiguous— VO2 max is highly correlated with longevity. High intensity training is important to improve glycolytic capacity. We lose glycolytic capacity as we age and it’s important to stimulate it. For VO2 max, high intensity training, Peter prescribes patients to do a 4×4 protocol. 4 minutes of the highest intensity, sustained exercise followed by 4 minutes of recovery. Repeat this 4-6x. Add a warm up and cool down on either end and this will be a little over an hour.

title: Mitochondrial Function and Aging
content: Longevity is also highly related with mitochondrial function and metabolic health. There’s an aging process where we lose mitochondrial function, and there’s a sedentary component where we lose mitochondrial function. Increasing mitochondrial function takes months or years. Increasing the glycolytic system takes much less time, weeks or months. If you stimulate the glycolytic system 2-3 days you’ll see progress. Add a high intensity interval 2-3 days a week at the end of that Zone 2 training, and you’ll target both energy systems: the oxidative mitochondrial system and the glycolytic energy system.

title: Metformin and Mitochondrial Function
content: Studies are ongoing to see if the impairment of mitochondrial function or elevated lactate levels seen in patients taking metformin is an artifact of the drug or is a real effect. We know that metformin inhibits complex I, which is key for mitochondrial function. It’s part of the electron transport chain.

title: Supplements and Mitochondrial Function
content: Precursors to NAD are common (NR or NMN). Are these clinically relevant? If you boost NAD in the plasma, is it boosted in the cell? Is it beneficial to the mitochondria? NAD is very important in glycolysis; it is needed to maintain redox status.

title: Lactate and Cancer
content: Lactate regulates genetic expression of the most important genes in breast cancer. Lacate is a mandatory byproduct of glycolysis. In 1923 Warburg characterized a high rate of glycolysis in cancer cells. What struct Warburg was not the amount of glucose used but the production of lactate. Iñigo’s work is showing that lactate is an oncometabolite. When there is a high glycolytic rate in cells, they will produce a lot of lactate.

title: Exercise and Cancer Metastasis
content: Exercise might be beneficial for many patients. Exosomes are microvesicles in the body that may be responsible for metastasis. Muscles also release exosomes. One of the benefits of exercise is the crosstalk between skeletal muscle and many organs. Could this be mediated through exosomes released by muscles? Could exosomes released by muscle cells keep cancer at bay?

title: Long COVID and Metabolic Parameters
content: A study of metabolic parameters of patients with long COVID was published. It was observed that mitochondria in long COVID patients (even in those who were previously healthy) look like those from people with type 2 diabetes in terms of fat oxidation and lactate production. People with long COVID struggle to breathe during simple tasks such as walking up stairs. A test of their pulmonary function looks normal. COVID affects cardiac muscles so their cardio function was measured; this too is normal. Next they undergo CPET testing, this is physiological, metabolic testing. They measure lactate as well.

title: Decline in Metabolic Health and Mitochondrial Function
content: Viruses can hijack the mitochondria for their own benefit, for reproduction— could COVID do the same thing? There are people with long COVID that improve in weeks or months; they go back to normal. But, there are a handful of people who after a year, have not improved one bit. Can exercise be used in a therapeutic way to stimulate mitochondrial function?

title: Using Cellular Surrogates of Metabolism for Prescribing Exercise
content: If you want to be precise about prescribing exercise, use cellular surrogates such as lactate levels and fat oxidation is better than VO2 max. Using METs (metabolic equivalents of task) is prehistoric. Declining mitochondrial function is a hallmark of aging. Zone 2 exercise is a way to measure mitochondrial function. Zone 2 exercise is both the treatment and the test.

title: Metabolomics and Sedentary Individuals
content: In sedentary individuals there is a decreased capacity of the mitochondria to oxidize fuels (pyruvate, fatty acids, and amino acids). There is also a significant decreases in the complexes that make up the electron transport chain. There is decreased capacity of the transporters that move different metabolites into the mitochondria. The transporter for pyruvate into the mitochondria is also dysregulated in sedentary individuals (as compared to active individuals). Similarly, oxidation of pyruvate in the mitochondria is dysregulated.

title: Cellular Changes in Metabolism of People with Diabetes and Metabolic Syndrome
content: People with diabetes/ metabolic syndrome have intramuscular triglycerides. These are fat droplets. This fat is not metabolically active, yet it continues to grow in size. Elite athletes also have intramuscular triglycerides but they are very active. 25-30% of the fat oxidation comes from that fat droplet. These fat droplets are constantly being turned over, oxidized and replenished. These intramuscular fat droplets in people with type 2 diabetes keep growing and they release proinflammatory molecules. About 80% of people with type 2 diabetes also have cardiovascular disease (and vice versa), which is why it is called cardiometabolic disease.
